qas.question: how much of the population have the rural plains lost since 1920?
who declated the American frontier "closed" in 1893?
how many ghost towns are in the state of Kansas?
how much prarie land does the "Buffalo Commons" want to return?
How many people lives per square mile on the Great Plains in 1900?
In what year was the Great Plains considered "open" to inhabitants and farm activity?
What's the school-age population of Kansas?
In what year was the "Buffalo Commons" proposal made?
How many high schools remain in Kansas?

context: The rural Plains have lost <a0_0>a third<a0_0/> of their population since 1920. Several hundred thousand square miles (several hundred thousand square kilometers) of the Great Plains have fewer than <b4_0>6<b4_0/> inhabitants per square mile (2.3 inhabitants per square kilometer)—the density standard <a1_0>Frederick Jackson Turner<a1_0/> used to declare the American frontier "closed" in <b5_0><b7_0>1893<b7_0/><b5_0/>. Many have fewer than 2 inhabitants per square mile (0.77 inhabitants per square kilometer). There are <a2_0>more than <b6_0><b8_0>6,000<b8_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> ghost towns in the state of Kansas alone, according to Kansas historian Daniel Fitzgerald. This problem is often exacerbated by the consolidation of farms and the difficulty of attracting modern industry to the region. In addition, the smaller school-age population has forced the consolidation of school districts and the closure of high schools in some communities. The continuing population loss has led some to suggest that the current use of the drier parts of the Great Plains is not sustainable, and there has been a proposal - the "Buffalo Commons" - to return approximately <a3_0>139,000 square miles<a3_0/> (360,000 km2) of these drier parts to native prairie land.
